Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear participants, on the online platform we uploaded a new and final constest for max clique. As requested this contains more harder instances. You can also access the new public instances on the course page.  Due to the limited time in the presentation you can focus your analysis on the old data, but for testing and the final ranking we will use the new data.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Dear Participants, the evaluation of the seminar is available this week by following this link or using the QR-code below. Filling the form takes 5-10 min and is very important for the student body, for me personally, and for the TU in general, so please consider taking the time, it's much appreciated! thanks and see y'all in 2 weeks (July 22) for the final presentations.

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Faculty IV is looking for tutors for all bachelor-level teaching and asked us to share the attached flyer with everyone. If that is your jam, please consider signing up for becoming a tutor :) Closing date for signups is July 15 (in 10 days).

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Guest Lecture on Monday about Profilers

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Dear Participants, it is my pleasure to announce, as indicated in the schedule, the "guest lecture" of Prof. Michel Steuwer from the Programming Languages Group of TU Berlin who has graciously agreed to give a gentle introduction to profilers. In particular, he will talk about and demonstrate the popular profilers VTune (Win/Linux) and Instruments (Mac). Everyone will also get the opportunity to play around a little with these tools so, in preparation, let me advise everyone to install one of these tools before Monday and maybe fiddle around with them a little if you're so inclined. If you're on Linux and have issues installing VTune, you can try a FOSS tool called perf which also has FOSS gui called hotspot; note: while these tools are not explicitly covered in the lecture, many profiler concepts will also apply to them. The lecture starts on Monday, July 8th at 12h sharp in MAR0.002. Looking forward to seeing y'all on Monday -Mathias Weller

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear students,  as mentioned in the code review lecture we would like to give you the opportunity to participate in a code review. This is optional, but to encourage you to participate we will give out bonus points towards your grade (4 Portfoliopoints = improvement of your grade by 0.33 (subject to change)) if you write a good code review.  Please fill out this questionnaire until Monday 23:59 if you would like to participate in the code review (please fill out only once per team). Teams that fill out the questionnaire will receive code from the 2nd milestone of another participating team (if you don't participate, your code will not be sent to anyone) Until 12th July you then do a code review of the code given to you: Write a 1+ page code review (this will later be sent to the team that wrote the code) (submit a single PDF, otherwise no strict format/layout/structure requirements) Your code review has no impact on the other teams grade Be kind in your code review. The focus should be on giving useful feedback for the other team Keep in mind the information conveyed in the code review lecture If you're referring to specific lines of code include them (inline code block), rather than referencing by line numbers+file. If you can find bugs, bottlenecks that can be easily fixed, or easy speedups that can be achieved, do point them out  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Hello all,  thank you to the teams that signed up so far.  We decided to do a few changes. You can register to take part in the code review until Thursday and we will send you code to review on Friday. We'll adjust the timeline accordingly.  Also we will award up to 6 Portfoliopoints for good code reviews.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Dear Participants, if you enjoy this course and are eager to show-off your algorithmic design prowess, there are multiple annually-helt competitions out there in the world, two of which are CG:SHOP - a computational geometry challenge organized by a team in TU Braunschweig PACE - a competition focussed on parameterized algorithms and heuristics organized by different teams Scoring high on such international competitions can look good on a CV and even get you invited to present your solvers on international conferences. However, competition is tough there. If you still would like to participate and require sponsorship/guidance, please talk to us and we'll see what we can do.

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear all, tomorrow are the presentations and if possible we would like to start at 12:00 already.  There will be two split groups: MAR 0.009: Teams 1,3,5,7,9 MAR 0.002: Teams 2,4,6,8,10  You can use our laptop for your presentation. In which case please upload your slides in the team forum (no deadline, just before your presenation). PDFs should work, no guarantee for power point.  The deadline for the handouts with the extension is Monday 9am.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear all,  the room allocation today will be the same  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear participants, yesterday you should have received the login data to access https://algeng.inet.tu-berlin.de/. Please upload your solver there until Monday 8am. Please also note the instructions in exercise sheet 2 on how to package your source code so that it can be accepted by the testing platform.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Here are some additional information on the testing environment:  Your submissions run on a server with an AMD EPYC 7551 32-Core Processor and 400GB of RAM. Your submissions are currently allowed to use 3 threads, and up to 8GB of RAM.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear participants, additional testing data is available on the course page. It includes more kinds of instances. The scripts had to be changed slightly so make sure to use the new scripts.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Christlinde Thielcke
Messages.Content: Wir möchten auf folgende Nachricht aus dem Mentoring der Fakultät IV hinweisen: Hallo! Ab sofort kannst du dich wieder als Mentor*in anmelden und wir freuen uns, wenn du dieses Jahr (wieder) dabei bist. Mentoring ist mehr als nur ein Modul, denn als Mentor*in profitierst du mindestens genauso davon wie hinterher die Erstis von dir. Auch in diesem Jahr haben wir Events für Mentor*innen geplant mit vielen Gelegenheiten, die Uni aus einer anderen Perspektive, mit neuen Möglichkeiten kennen zu lernen. Außerdem bieten wir dir zusätzlich: 3 LP Vorbereitungsschulungen, Feedbacktreffen und individuelle Begleitung Lerninhalte wie z.B. Gruppenleitung, Kommunikation, Motivation, Awareness u.v.m. Mentor*innenevents mit hohem Spaßfaktor Achso, du weißt noch gar nicht was deine Aufgabe als Mentor*in ist? Du begleitest im Team eine Gruppe von Erstis bei ihrem Start ins Studium. Wie genau das gedacht ist kannst du auf unserer Website erfahren oder auch in einem unserer kommenden Q&A Treffen. Komm vorbei und stelle deine Fragen.  Termine: Q&A Mentoring Meeting (online) Wann? 14. Juni 15:00-16:00 Uhr Wo? Zoom: https://tu-berlin.zoom.us/j/68007662297?pwd=s389c9ibzKQKHUKeEUzbzsNL3lweqb.1   Mentoring Warm-up mit ehemaligen Mentor*innen Wann? 5. Juli ab 17 Uhr Wo? Kulturfabrik Moabit  Q&A Mentoring (online) Wann? 22. August 15:00-16:00 Uhr Wo? Zoom: https://tu-berlin.zoom.us/j/68007662297?pwd=s389c9ibzKQKHUKeEUzbzsNL3lweqb.1   Natürlich kannst du uns auch jederzeit eine Mail schreiben (mentoring@eecs.tu-berlin.de), anrufen (+49 30 314 -73194) oder vorbeikommen (MAR 6.006).   Wir freuen uns auf jeden Fall, wenn du dieses Jahr Teil des Mentorings bist. Viele Grüße  Luis & Maria

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Dear Participants, First, as indicated earlier, we would really like to give everyone the opportunity (and a few tools) to do a (proper) code review, as this is something considered essential in the industry. I am preparing a short "lecture" for Monday introducing and motivating code reviews, as well as giving some pointers on how to conduct one. Although I'm not an expert either, I hope to still spark a discussion and maybe give enough pointers so that everyone can at least start to conduct a code review and/or prepare their own code for such a review. Regarding the actual review, we are considering giving a few "bonus"-portfolio-points for conducting one. Around the time of the second milestone, we will probably ask every team whether they want to participate in the reviewing and, if so, try to organize "review circles" partitioned by employed programming language. Second, as I do consider myself somewhat of a C++-enthusiast, I feel that I can maybe teach the teams that are coding in C++ some indications that may help them keep their code clean and efficient, as well as enable a few participants to give a more effective code review, should they decide to participate in the process. Both "lectures" will be given back-to-back (maybe with a break) on the coming Monday, June 3 in MAR0.002 starting 12h15. Neither of them is mandatory, everyone can decide for themselves whether they want to come. Slides will be uploaded to ISIS. In particular, if you have no previous knowledge of C++ the second lecture will probably not provide alot to take home. The first lecture will be more general and not language-dependant. Looking forward to seeing y'all on Monday -Mathias Weller

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Preliminary data and script for testing

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear all, under the "Additional Material" section is a zip with scripts and data that you can use for local testing and development.  We will add more data and launch the online platform for testing next week. The instances currently consist mostly of quite simple instances, with a few slightly harder ones. We expect you to be able to solve most of these by the next milestone.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Dear Participants, please recall the the presentations of your literature-review shall be helt on Monday next week (in 7 days) in MAR (I suppose MAR007 as last time). In the meantime, if you want us to give you some feedback on your presentation slides and handout, please send me an Email with the appropriate attachments by Thursday. When you practice your talk, keep in mind that 1. it shall fit in the 15min slot, 2. the literature review and the presentation should be a team-effort 3. active participation also with respect to the other talks is expected.

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Dear Participants, I am happy that many of you took me up on the offer of commenting on their slides/handout, and since it might also be interesting for the other groups, I would like to share some of the more common pieces of advice that I gave:  first and foremost, keep in mind the role and goal of having a handout, in particular in context of a literature-review presentation: the handout should help attendees of your talk who want to quickly look something up that they might have forgotten, but is important for the slide that is currently showing. Such information has to be retrieved in a glance, without having to read through alot of text. Therefore, your handout... needs to be well-structured, following the structure of your presentation; I recommend having different subsections about: (i) exact/parameterized algorithms (ii) data-reduction (iii) upper-/lower-bounds (iv) heuristics/approximation (which actually are lower bounds... you'll figure something out) should be concise without lyrical boiler-plate does not need an introduction to/motivation of the clique problem (you can define it if you want) does not need a conclusion/outlook (again, not a paper) remember that your handout should not replace, but support your talk. on the subject of structure, it can be helpful to use proper definition- and theorem- environments; they don't need to contain alot of text; remember to use bulletpoint lists when listing things, also in definitions/theorems it can also be helpful to guide the attendees attention by hightlighting some keywords (sparsely! don't overdo it) using bold font; this further reduces the time it takes to find a concept that I might want to look up again during the presentation the literature-review is not about what you plan to implement, but what people have been doing in the past to solve the problem, what strategies are there, which ones worked well on what kinds of inputs, etc. EDIT: actually, it's fine to include a final section about what you're planning to implement, sorry for the confusion. you can put pseudocode on your handout, but don't overdo it, communicate ideas rather than code. For example, it is way more useful to me to read "compute a maximal independent set" than to look at the pseudocode that does it if you have space, put a figure to illustrate complicated concepts; even better if the figure also occurs in your presentation, then I can visually match them put running times/kernel sizes in the handout, we want to see lots of O(...)s  I hope this helps everyone improve their handouts and maybe even their presentations and I'm looking forward to seeing what everyone found out on Monday.

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: A last-minute addition maybe: if you're having issues fitting everything on the handout, remember that the template is just a guide that you can diverge from. For example, you are free to play with margins, negative \vspace, paralist's compactitem and compactenum, as well as font sizes. If you still have problems fitting everything you need on the handout in 2 pages (including references), try to cut down some unimportant references for the print version and make a seperate digital version that may exceed 2 pages.  In any case (and I forgot to tell you this, mea culpa): please send the handout (both versions if you made a seperate online version) to me in time (at least 2h before our session on Monday), so I can print/upload them.

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Someone pointed out that there is an ISIS submission for the handout for Saturday. That's the correct date indeed, sorry for the confusion. However, if you want to submit a >2-page digital handout as well, I'll take it by email and I'll upload it to the ISIS page for everyone to use on their devices during the presentation.

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Dear all, we will offer a "catch up" lecture on Monday 13.05.2024 from 12 till 14 in MAR 0.002.  We will cover basic concepts from algorithm engineering that are essential in this course. This is mainly targeted towards students who have no attended an algorithm engineering course for NP-hard problems before.  We will cover topics such as fixed-parameter tractability, data reduction rules, search trees and lower/upper bounds.  See you there!  Best, Aleksander

We still have sufficient capacity. If you would like to participate contact us via email.  In case you decided not to take part in this course or other issues please let us know as soon as possible.  For the topic we decided to assign everyone Max Clique, since it was rated high by almost everyone. We hope this works well for you.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Dear participants, we would like to apologize for taking this long to announce the first meeting of the course. This is due to a conflict in room-assignments that could, unfortunately, not be resolved. We will thus hold the kick-off meeting online this Wednesday, April the 24th from 14h to 16h in this room. Each of the two organizing groups (INET and AKT) will give a short presentation about the available topic(s) and there will be information about the organization of the course, as well as some hints for independant literature research. The slides will be made available afterwards. Please note that we currently have way more sign-ups in the course than there is capacy (12 teams x 3 people per team). This means that not everyone can take part in the course and there will be a (random) selection process after the kick-off meeting. Please be sure to fill-in the poll in oder to have a chance at that.

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Submissions pending for a long time

Messages.Author: Eloi-Noel Sandt
Messages.Content: Hello, I was trying to upload our solver (Team 5) to the platform but after a first failed attempt, succeeding attempts remain pending (submitted more than 12 hours ago). Not sure why this happens, the solver compiles on our systems with the specified cmake and g++ versions.  Best, Eloi

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Hello Eloi,  sorry the system just silently failed without reporting a compilation issue to you. The system wasn't able to parse the cmake file correctly to determine the final executable name. It was expecting a binary literally called ${PROJECT_NAME}.  I resubmitted your last submission, but I changed add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} ... ) into add_executable(mc_solver ...) and now the system works correctly. The submission is currently running. You should have some results in an hour or so.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Eloi-Noel Sandt
Messages.Content: Thanks a lot! :)

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: Hello Michelle,  the testing website and the scripts we provided on ISIS should be functionally the same, just we test with more data on the website. If your program runs successfully with the provided scripts then it should also run on the testing platform without any changes from your side.  Here is some more info on the last few submissions on the testing website  the last 3 zips that were uploaded just contain an empty folder "src_clean" and no .py files.  the first submission doesn't run, and fails with this error:  Traceback (most recent call last): File "/tmp/sioworkers_ls3c_rbr/urn:uuid:53ab7eca-137e-4e83-93aa-ce67e6b49779/src_clean/main.py", line 2, in from helper import create_edgelist File "/tmp/sioworkers_ls3c_rbr/urn:uuid:53ab7eca-137e-4e83-93aa-ce67e6b49779/src_clean/helper.py", line 3, in from sortedcontainers import SortedList ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'sortedcontainers'  We do not have many pip packages preinstalled, just some basic ones like numpy and networkx. I'll add sortedcontainers in a bit.  Best, Aleksander

Messages.Author: Michelle Kappl
Messages.Content: Ahh perfect. Yes, I was trying some things out to get the submission to work.  Could you install the module sortedcontainers?

Messages.Author: Aleksander Figiel
Messages.Content: It's added now. I'm rerunning your first two submissions. It might take an hour or two for both results to update.

Messages.Author: Batuhan Hakan Erdem
Messages.Content: Can we do the presentation and the handout in German?

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: The handout should be in English, you can ask a large language model to correct your grammar if you like (just don't ask it to do your literature review for you). English will also be mandatory in MAR0.009 since we have people who communicated that they do not speak German. In the spirit of fairness, we'd also have to mandate English for the other group, but if you really cannot give a presentation in English and are not assigned to MAR0.009, then you can try to negotiate with Aleksander Figiel and Prof. Schmid. However, even if they do allow presentations in German, those would have to be the first presentations of the session, since we're planning on merging the groups after the first 3 presentations (so we'd have non-German-speakers in the room starting with the 4th presentation). This also implies that, if more then 3 groups ask to do their presentation in German, we'd have to deny all of them.

Messages.Author: Simeon Pawlowski
Messages.Content: Quick reminder to anyone like me who almost forgot.

Messages.Author: Anja Katharina Ilg
Messages.Content: Hi everyone, our team is unsure about the schedule.  When will be the first lecture/meeting?  When do we start researching/programming?  When do we register? LG Anja

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Hello Anja, our team is unsure about the schedule. The general schedule is published on the ISIS course page under "Schedule".  When will be the first lecture/meeting? The kick-off meeting was helt on April 24. There will probably be a lecture to bring everyone who did not participate in Algorithm Engineering 1 up to speed, next Monday or the week after. The first meetings with presentations from participants will be on Monday, May 27.  When do we start researching/programming? As you now know that all teams will work on the same problem (MaxClique), you can start researching now. It's not a good idea to start coding without an idea of what algorithms exist, so I would not start programming right away. Do some research before and prepare the first milestone presenation.  When do we register? Everyone who participated in the topic selection should register in MOSES as soon as possible. Registration is open until mid May (if you missed that deadline, please contact us via email and we'll see what we can do).

Messages.Author: Michelle Kappl
Messages.Content: Hello Mathias,  Our question intended to find out more about the organization of the course thats not on ISIS. Will there be a lecture to find out ... - What are the contents of the milestone presentations in detail and what are the requirements? - When do we get the tools to upload our Code? - When will we get the examples? - What are the exercise sheets?  Will all this be part of the lecture next Monday?  Kind regards, Michelle

Messages.Author: Mathias Weller
Messages.Content: Hello Michelle, while we intended to do much less "hand-holding" in this project than in Algorithm Engineering 1, we decided to provide a short overview over the most important (general) techniques used to attack computationally hard problems (such as MaxClique). That's what the upcoming "lecture" will be about. We will upload (to ISIS) some pieces of information about what we expect in your milestone presentation and report, and how to give a convincing presentation, as well as templates for slides and reports.  Now, to answer your questions:  What are the contents of the milestone presentations in detail and what are the requirements? For Milestone 1 ("literature research"), you're supposed to review available literature about how other people have solved MaxClique before and what problems they encountered. Remember that we're interested in exact solutions, but heuristics and approximation algorithms may still be useful to provide upper bounds. Interesting results include, but are not limited to: parameterized algorithms other exact algorithms preprocessing and kernelization ILP-formulations upper-bound techniques lower-bound techniques For Milestone 2 ("implementation"), you're supposed to produce a working implementation of promising algorithms that you found in the first part (milestone 1), that is, implement an exact solver (which may use data-reduction as well as upper-bound heuristics). In the presentation, we would like to see some details and maybe some first tests on the instances that we'll provide. Try to find a way of judging whether certain tricks (found in the first part or thought-of yourself) are advantagous.  For Milestone 3 ("algorithm engineering"), you're supposed to go through "The Algorithm Engineering Cycle". If you're unsure of what that means, we'll give some pointers, but basically, you run your implementation, understand why its slow for some instances, analyze the problematic instances in order to come up with strategies to improve performance, and repeat.   When do we get the tools to upload our Code? Once Milestone 1 has been passed.  When will we get the examples? I suppose you're referring to the "public instances" that you can run your solver on to test its performance? We're currently working on generating those, but we'd like you to do the literature research for the first milestone without bias on the particular types of instances that will be provided.  What are the exercise sheets? I'm not sure what you mean, what exercise sheets?

Messages.Author: Simeon Pawlowski
Messages.Content: The exercise sheets were from the course materials of AlgEng 1, which were mistakenly visible for some time.

Messages.Author: Abedelmunem Razzouk

Messages.Content: Hello,  there will be no lecture today. By default unless announced or written in the schedule there won't be anything on the Monday slot.  However, there might be a short lecture next Monday, we will have to see and announce it.  Best, Aleksander

The meeting will thus likely be online, on Wednesday, 14h-16h. A public announcement with the definitive date will follow shortly.

Messages.Content: It's an exception, the Monday slot remains unchanged.
